info: Overview of debt and financing arrangements across multiple instruments including revolving credit facility, senior notes, asset-backed notes and working capital facilities, with multiple date references from 2023-01-01 to 2024-12-31, indicating a diversified funding structure; no explicit monetary amounts provided in the chunk.

Governance and market presence updates show multiple membership records for Tesla, including US and DE country memberships with end dates in 2023 and 2024, Automotive and Energy Generation and Storage segment memberships for 2023 and 2024, a 2022 period for OtherCountriesMember, and Ira Ehrenpreis joining as a member with periods in 2024 (Jan 1–Dec 31 and Oct 1–Dec 31) plus a year-end 2024 endpoint.

Tesla, Inc.'s 2024 Form 10-K includes forward-looking statements with risks described in Risk Factors and provides corporate details: principal offices in Austin, TX (1 Tesla Road, 78725); IRS EIN 91-2197729; phone 512-516-8177; common stock trades as TSLA on The Nasdaq Global Select Market. The filing notes that, as of June 28, 2024, the aggregate market value of voting stock held by non-affiliates was 550.17 billion and that as of January 22, 2025 there were 3,216,517,037 shares outstanding.

Tesla operates two reportable segments (automotive and energy generation/storage) with a five-vehicle lineup (Model 3, Y, S, X and Cybertruck), Model Y seating up to seven, Cybertruck deliveries starting in 2023, and Semi production since 2022. Planned Robotaxi launch in 2025 and ongoing AI/self-driving/Optimus initiatives are complemented by expanded manufacturing footprint (4 US facilities: CA, NY, TX, NV; 2 international facilities in China and Germany) and a Monterrey Gigafactory announced in 2023. Supercharger/NACS rollout includes adoption by other automakers beginning in 2024 and NACS vehicle production by no later than 2025. IRA incentives include federal EV tax credits up to 7500 for vehicles and 6-50% credits for standalone energy storage, with insurance offered in 12 states and a tax-credit phaseout around 2032.

Regulatory credits and incentives relevant to investors include credits for zero-emission vehicle operations and energy storage, with energy storage credits (6-50%) and solar credits (6-70%) under IRA/IRC, phasing out starting in 2032 or later. The company highlights federal and state programs affecting energy storage revenue, including FERC participation in wholesale markets and procurement targets/net metering. Regulation of vehicle safety, testing, and evolving self-driving rules add regulatory complexity across the U.S. and international markets. Competitive dynamics in automotive and energy generation/storage persist. ESG and human capital initiatives emphasize responsible sourcing, workforce development, and retention. As of 12/31/2024 Tesla employed 125,665 worldwide; 92% of employees have stock ownership participation; 68% of managers were promoted internally; 45% of management has been with Tesla for more than five years. US veterans are 2.3%, individuals with disabilities are 3.3%, and veterans with disabilities are 1.2%. Internships/Fellowships total ~4,000 annually; START program expanded to 14 campuses with over 400 technicians hired; Education Assistance program has supported 5,436 actively enrolled learners and 1,338 graduates in 2024.

Tesla highlights significant production ramp risks and supplier dependencies as it scales across multiple factories worldwide, including battery cell sourcing from Panasonic and CATL with plans for in-house cells; notes potential delays in new products, AI services, and energy products amid regulatory, supply chain, and cost volatility risks, plus intense automotive and energy storage competition; management cites employee engagement via the Pulse survey with 86% participation to inform future goals.

Product quality and safety risks, liability exposure, and regulatory/compliance challenges could affect Tesla's ability to develop, market, and sell products; potential recalls, warranty costs and self-insurance exposure; financing and residual value risks in vehicle leasing; SUNY Gigafactory New York obligations; dependence on Elon Musk and potential labor/union risks; cybersecurity and data/privacy risks; debt covenants and funding constraints.

Investor-relevant risks: warranty reserves are uncertain and may materially impact results; insurance coverage may be insufficient; debt covenants could restrict operations and liquidity; potential lack of funds for additional financing; obsolescence of manufacturing equipment could accelerate depreciation; indebtedness totaling about 7910000000 as of year-end 2024 increases vulnerability; currency fluctuations may affect margins; intellectual property infringement and licensing costs; ESG scrutiny could raise costs; exposure to natural disasters, geopolitical events and regulatory changes; reliance on government incentives for EVs and solar could be reduced; data privacy/cybersecurity compliance costs; regulatory risks to direct-to-consumer sales and Autopilot/FSD; ongoing government investigations could entail penalties or costs; stock price volatility is expected.

Regulatory and legislative risk to direct-to-consumer vehicle sales domestically and internationally, including state dealer licensing constraints and evolving franchise laws; stock price volatility and litigation risk; 2024 highlights include 1,773,000 vehicles produced, 1,789,000 delivered, 31.4 GWh energy storage deployed, revenue of 97.69B, net income 7.09B, and robust cash generation with 36.56B in cash/investments and 14.92B operating cash flow; large capex of 11.34B; ongoing AI/software and expansion investments; 50-year land rights; convertible notes at 2 percent; warrants exercised for 2,894,424 shares; IPO price around 1.13; 52-week range 488.54 to 138.80; 9,512 holders of record as of 1/22/2025.

Tesla's 2025 outlook centers on expanding manufacturing capacity (including Cybertruck, Semi and next-gen platform vehicles), increasing Gigafactory ramp capacity to installed levels, and advancing battery-cell self-manufacturing; the company notes risks from supply, labor, macroeconomic and geopolitical factors that could cause production volatility during multi-continent ramps. Notable items include the 2024 Powerwall 3 launch, Megafactory ramps in Shanghai and Lathrop, and the 2025 New Model Y worldwide launch in Q1 2025. Capital expenditures are expected to exceed $11 billion in 2025 and in each of the following two fiscal years (2026 and 2027). The company anticipates production ramps across three continents and mentions potential near-term declines during ramp stages, such as the first quarter of 2024 due to Model 3 ramp and Berlin factory shutdowns.

Tax positions require significant judgement; open audits may affect income tax expense and final outcomes may differ from expectations. 2024 revenue mix shows automotive revenue down 8% YoY due to pricing and deliveries, offset by Cybertruck ramp and $596 million of FSD revenue; automotive regulatory credits rose to $2.763 billion; leasing declined; services and other grew; energy generation and storage revenue rose; total revenues increased about 1% to 97,690 (mm). Gross margins shifted: automotive 18.4% in 2024 vs 19.4% in 2023; total gross margin 17.9% in 2024.

Tesla 2024 results show automotive margin compression (total automotive 18.4% in 2024 vs 19.4% in 2023) and automotive & services margin decline (16.9% in 2024 vs 18.2% in 2023) driven by lower selling prices and Cybertruck ramp, while Energy Generation and Storage margin expanded to 26.2% (from 18.9%). Energy revenue costs rose 2.55B (52%) due to Megapack/Powerwall deployments but benefited from IRA credits and a higher‑margin storage mix. R&D rose 571M (+14%) with a higher R&D as a % of revenue (5% in 2024 vs 4% in 2023). SG&A rose 350M (+7%), aided by facilities (+171M), personnel/labor (+115M) and marketing (+57M). In Q2 2024, restructuring actions drove 583M of employee termination expenses. Interest income rose to 1.569B (up 503M, +47%), and Other income (expense), net improved by 523M, led by bitcoin fair value remeasurement and foreign‑currency effects. Provision for income taxes swung to 1.837B in 2024 (vs a 5.001B benefit in 2023), with an effective tax rate of 20% in 2024 versus (50)% in 2023; valuation allowance related to US deferred tax assets was released in 2023 (~6.54B). These items underscore a mix of margin dynamics across segments, aggressive cost initiatives, and tax assets/churn impacting reported profitability.

Tesla's 2024 tax notes show a 6.84B increase in current tax provision as the tax rate shifted to a 20% expense in 2024 from a 50% benefit in 2023, driven largely by releasing the valuation allowance on U.S. deferred tax assets in 4Q 2023. The company notes ongoing consideration of deferred tax asset realizability, with exceptions for California assets, U.S. foreign tax credits and certain foreign losses. Liquidity remains strong with cash and short-term investments totaling about 37.8B, plus $5.0B of unused committed credit. In 2024, debt outstanding was 7.91B (current 2.35B) and lease liabilities were 7.05B (current 1.19B). Management reiterates capex to exceed 11.0B in 2025 and the next two fiscal years. Cash flow highlights for 2024: operating 14.92B, investing (18.79)B, financing 3.85B. Capital expenditures in 2024 were 11.34B with 7.45B of investments purchased; 2023 figures were 8.90B capex and 6.62B investments. FX risk could affect net income by about 1.15B in 2024 and 1.01B in 2023 with 10% adverse moves. Debt issuance proceeds rose by 1.81B in 2024 and debt repayments rose by 1.15B. Warranties are noted as a critical audit matter.

Total automotive warranty reserve of 6,716 million as of 12/31/2024; reserve reflects management’s best estimate of future repair, replacement costs and recalls; noted as a critical audit matter with procedures including controls testing, historical claims review, and the involvement of professionals to develop an independent estimate for certain Tesla vehicle models.

Tesla 2024 results show total revenues of 97,690 million with net income of 7,153 million. Revenue mix: Automotive sales 72,480; regulatory credits 2,763; energy generation and storage sales 9,564; services and other 10,534; leasing contributions 1,827 (auto) and 522 (energy). Operating cash flow 14,923 million; investing cash flow -18,787; financing cash flow 3,853; year-end cash and equivalents 17,037. Deferred revenue for automotive services ended at 3,599 with 1,343 additions and 840 million expected to be recognized in the next 12 months. The notes discuss GAAP consolidation of VIEs, estimates, and resale value guarantees.

Significant deferred revenue and financing data across Automotive and Energy segments. As of 12/31/2024, large unsatisfied performance obligations exist: automotive regulatory credits total $4.68B (>1 year) with $0.863B to be recognized in the next 12 months; energy generation and storage contracts total $7.18B (>1 year) with $4.51B to be recognized in the next 12 months. Revenue recognized from deferred revenue in 2024 was $0.872B for automotive and $1.27B for energy generation/storage (2023: $0.469B and $0.571B). Energy storage deferred revenue balances for customer payments total $1.77B (2023: $1.60B), with related deferred revenue from leases $164M (2023: $181M). The company holds financing receivables: automotive current $247M vs $242M prior year, long-term $821M vs $1.04B; energy financing current $34M vs $31M, long-term $658M vs $578M. Leasing revenues: direct vehicle operating leasing $1.78B in 2024, $1.86B in 2023, $1.75B in 2022, with upfront lease payments deferred $394M (2024) and $458M (2023). Manufacturing credits: automotive $625M (2024) vs $359M (2023); energy generation/storage credits $756M (2024) vs $115M (2023). Qualifying vehicle leases can run up to 48 months.

Liquidity remains strong with total cash and restricted cash of 17,037 million at 12/31/2024; interest income on short-term investments was 763 million in 2024 and 388 million in 2023. Net income attributable to common stockholders: 7,091 (2024) vs 14,997 (2023) and 12,556 (2022); basic net income: 7,130 (2024) and 14,999 (2023) and 12,583 (2022); diluted net income: 7,130 (2024) 14,999 (2023) 12,584 (2022). Dilution arises from stock-based awards (292/298/310), convertible notes (1/2/3) and warrants (8/11/32); potentially dilutive shares excluded: 15 (2024), 12 (2023), 4 (2022). At year-end 2024, solar energy systems gross cost 6,790; accumulated depreciation 1,860; operating lease vehicles gross cost 7,030; accumulated depreciation 1,450. Foreign currency gains: 57 (2024), 122 (2023), -89 (2022). Government rebates receivable current portion: 315 (2024) and 378 (2023); long-term portion 207 for both. MyPower notes receivable total: 248 (2024) and 266 (2023); 4 and 5 due within 12 months. No entity represented 10% or more of total receivables.

Currency fluctuations produced net gains of $57 million in 2024, $122 million in 2023, and a $89 million loss in 2022. Warranty reserves are substantial and rising, with end-of-period accrued warranty of $6,716 million in 2024 and related costs/provisions disclosed for 2024–2022, reflecting ongoing automotive warranty exposure. Government incentives include IRA-related cost reductions, Nevada tax incentives up to $195 million, and Texas property tax grant funding (70–80% of property taxes), with 401(k) employer contributions of $107 million, $99 million and $91 million in 2024–2022. The company adopted the new crypto assets accounting standard in 2024, holding Bitcoin at 11,509 units (cost basis $386 million; fair value $1,074 million) and total digital assets fair value of $1,076 million, including $204 million of impairment in 2022 and $589 million of unrealized gains in 2024; ending digital assets fair value was $1,076 million.

Unaudited adoption of the crypto assets standard increased Digital assets, net by 347 million with a 77 million tax impact and a 270 million contribution to net income attributable to common stockholders for the three months ended December 31, 2024, and resulted in an 0.08 per-share impact on both basic and diluted EPS. No impairment losses were recorded in 2024. Goodwill in the automotive segment declined to 244 million from 253 million (down 9 million) while intangible assets declined to 150 million from 178 million (down 28 million). Inventory write-downs were 190 million in 2024, 233 million in 2023 and 144 million in 2022. As of December 31, 2024, cash and cash equivalents were 14,386 million; certificates of deposit and time deposits were 12,767 million; U.S. government securities 3,620 million; commercial paper 3,919 million; corporate debt securities 118 million; money market funds 1,753 million; digital assets 1,076 million; total cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments were 36,563 million; and most short-term investments mature within one year.

As of December 31, 2024, most short-term investments mature within one year; carrying values of financial instruments not re-measured at fair value approximate fair value. Inventory totaled 12017 million in 2024 (13626 million in 2023) with write-downs of 190 million in 2024, 233 million in 2023, and 144 million in 2022. Depreciation expense was 4.12 billion in 2024. PPE totaled 51424 million in 2024 (41782 million in 2023) with accumulated depreciation 15588 million in 2024 and 12057 million in 2023. Accrued liabilities and other current liabilities totaled 10723 million in 2024 and 9080 million in 2023; other long-term liabilities totaled 10495 million in 2024 and 8153 million in 2023. Debt as of 12/31/2024 includes a revolver with up to 5000 million commitment expiring in 2028, with two optional extensions; recourse debt total 7 million, non-recourse debt total 7900 million, total debt 7907 million, and total debt and finance leases 8213 million. Automotive Asset-backed Notes outstanding 4329 million in 2024; Energy Asset-backed Notes 493 million; Cash Equity Debt 338 million. China Working Capital Facility outstanding 2740 million; 2024 Automotive Asset-backed Notes issued principal 2450 million with net proceeds 2440 million; 2024 notes matured and warrants settled with 11.4 million shares issued.

ppe.category: Machinery, equipment, vehicles and office furniture

data.china_working_capital_facility_maturity_: April 2025, renewable until March 2026; refinanced long-term

info: 2024 securitization activity included Automotive Asset-backed Notes totaling $2.45B principal (net proceeds $2.44B) and Energy Asset-backed Notes totaling $499M principal (net proceeds $494M); SPEs are consolidated with no recourse to corporate assets. A China Working Capital Facility was established: unsecured revolving facility up to RMB 20.0B with interest at LPR minus 1.18%. Pledged assets at 12/31/2024 were $5.16B, up from $4.64B at 12/31/2023. Leases reflect significant operating and finance lease assets and liabilities, with 2024 total lease expense of $1.93B and weighted-average remaining terms of 7.9 years (operating) and 4.4 years (finance). The company also has $502M aggregate principal debt issued in 2016 as cash equity debt and 113.0M shares reserved under the 2019 Equity Incentive Plan.

Overview of the 2019 Equity Incentive Plan and ESPP: 113.0 million shares reserved/available for issuance under the 2019 Plan as of 12/31/2024; ESPP has 95.5 million shares available for issuance; 2024 ESPP issued 2.2M shares (2.1M in 2023, 1.4M in 2022); stock options and RSUs vest over four years with a 10-year exercise period; notable SBC activity and tax impacts in 2024 include total SBC expense of $1.999B, with pre-tax tax benefits from SBC of $371M, and unrecognized SBC expense of $5.79B related to non-performance awards expected to vest over ~3.0 years. Grant-date fair values and intrinsic values for stock options and RSUs are disclosed, along with risk/valuation assumptions (Black-Scholes) and ESPP specifics (15% payroll deduction, 85% purchase price).

Deferred tax position shows a net deferred tax asset of $6.422B as of 12/31/2024 (net of a $1.22B valuation allowance), driven by federal/state NOL carryforwards, R&D and other tax credits, and lease/GILTI-related assets, with total deferred tax assets of $11.962B and liabilities of $4.316B. Valuation allowance increased by $332M in 2024 due mainly to California assets, U.S. credits and foreign losses; federal/state NOLs total $4.34B and $8.59B respectively; federal RD credits total $1.48B, federal renewable energy credits $1.01B, and state RD credits $1.06B. The company has a $309M unrecognized withholding tax liability tied to indefinitely reinvested foreign earnings, ongoing IRS/state examinations, and sizable lease commitments (US NY: $5.0B over 10 years; Shanghai: RMB14.08B spend with RMB2.23B annual tax revenue). A gross unrecognized tax benefit balance is $1.417B as of 12/31/2024, with year-by-year changes noted from 2021 through 2024.

Tesla faces multiple ongoing lawsuits and investigations related to discrimination, harassment, and consumer and securities claims, including a CRD suit filed February 9, 2022 and an EEOC matter filed September 28, 2023, plus stockholder derivative actions filed June 16, 2022 and several proposed class actions concerning Autopilot/FSD and repairs. The company intends to vigorously defend these matters; outcomes and potential losses are not currently estimable. Also notes regulatory inquiries and that unused letters of credit totaled $448 million as of December 31, 2024, with Note 15 describing VIE arrangements.

info: Long-lived assets by geography show total 40760 million in 2024, with US 32461; Germany 4175; and other international 4124; compared with total 34954 million in 2023 (US 26629; Germany 4258; other international 4067). Inventory by reportable segment totaled 12017 million in 2024 (Automotive 9988; Energy generation and storage 2029) vs 13626 million in 2023 (Automotive 11139; Energy generation and storage 2487). In 2024 a restructuring action led to 583000000 of employee termination expenses, largely paid from an immaterial year-end accrual. In 2022 there were impairment losses of 204000000 and gains of 64000000 from converting digital assets to fiat, plus 36000000 of other termination expenses. Internal controls over financial reporting were evaluated as effective as of 2024. A director adopted a Rule 10b5-1 trading plan on December 6, 2024, generating 15000000 in net proceeds from exercising 761961 shares, with an expiration of 2025-06-03.

SolarCity filed a series of supplemental indentures in 2015 related to its 4.70%–5.75% Solar Bonds, across multiple Series (2015/C27-10 through 2015/C72-15). The filings span April 21, 2015 to July 21, 2015, indicating debt documentation activity rather than operational updates.

Exhibits show 18 supplemental indentures for SolarCity’s 2015 bond series, with coupon rates ranging 4.70% to 5.75% and dates from July 31 to November 30, 2015, reflecting ongoing debt-financing activity and filings.
